admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The Medium-Sized Cities Development
            Project for China achieved a satisfactory outcome. The
            objectives to increase efficiency in the utilization and
            management of existing facilities and to support expansion
            of economic activity were substantially achieved. The
            objectives to improve overall city planning and management
            and to strengthen resource mobilization varied by city and
            by sector. Bank performance during preparation and
            supervision was broadly satisfactory. However, there were
            some notable deficiencies relating to the ambitious scope of
            the project and a lack of early continuity in the project
            team. Borrower performance was satisfactory given the
            complexity of the project and inexperience of the
            municipalities, but was uneven among cities.
            Changzhou's performance was excellent, Luoyang's
            adequate overall, and Shashi's less than satisfactory.
            The sustainability of project achievements is likely, as:
            the new or improved approaches introduced under the project
            are consistent with the country's overall transition;
            the assets created under the project are valuable to the
            economies; and responsibilities for operation and
            maintenance of the assets are clear and the organizations
            responsible have the necessary financial and institutional
            capacities. Key lessons learned are as follows.
            Multi-sectoral projects in urban areas are both needed and
            feasible. These projects could provide a better platform for
            improvement of broad urban management systems and sectoral
            policies, compared with single-sector projects. However,
            they pose significant difficulties and risks. They require
            investment of substantial borrower and Bank resources
            throughout the project cycle. Policy and institutional
            development goals must be clearly defined and feasible.
